text: I haven’t, because I generally like being able to know that files across environments are exactly the same. But perhaps I should start looking into changing my workflow, at least for HubSpot projects.

In a multilanguage webiste (HubSpot CMS)
Do you know how to automatically redirect user based on IP ?
Thanks !
Or based on navigator language ?
Does anyone use Swift (Apple's programming language for macOS, iOS, watchOS and tvOS) to incorporate HubSpot data in their applications?
At <@U3TR96G84>, it looks like we don't have `{{ request.browserLanguage }}` supported right now but that can be added
How can I use Language Switcher on blog cause he doesn’t appeared

<@U3TR96G84> You can set cookies or local storage so if you select a certain language that it will change any link to the blog with the correct url. Kinda a sledge hammer approach but it would work. I have used that technique on other site for similar reasons.

<@U3TR96G84> I may be misinformed here but I thought when Multilanguage was in beta it was detecting language based on browser language by default and that was the default language it serves. Is that not correct? does it serve English by default?
found a funny in the core HubSpot CSS file :smirk_cat:
<@U3TR96G84> did you do your footer as a HubSpot menu? On the other hand what <@U38EZFVFE> said about cookie storage is the best solution so far

Any idea why `#single-cap-form input[type="radio"]:checked + span{color:black!important;}` works for styling a radio buttons clicked state for text color, but there is virtually no way to change the background color of a button in its' clicked state using similar markup?
I assume I need to over-ride some default HubSpot styling with an `!important` but, I've had zero luck

I'm positive that this: `.inputs-list li` is the class I need to target in its clicked state but, ` #single-cap-form input[type="radio"]:checked + .inputs-list li{background:white !important;}` doesn't do it
What you're targeting there is "a list item in an `.inputs-list` which is immediately adjacent to a checked radio button in `#single-cap-form`", which is just not how the markup is
Why not add it to the same `+ span` rule?
<@U3A4KEWK1> Hey Ian, thanks for the response. I've tried applying to the span rule, but no luck.
I've tested the just about every combo, just not sure how the CSS should be structured. I know it is the li itself that needs its background changed.
Well, the radio button is inside the li, and you can't really target element ancestors with CSS
If you want the background around the radio button as well, I'd make the span cover the entire area of the li, add some padding-left, and position the button absolutely inside that padding
Thanks! this seemed to work. Though there is about a 1px gap on the left and right of the span.
Everytime you refresh it will submit.
We're not refreshing, though
When you land on the page it submits once the page is done loading and redirects to the thank-you page
<@U6GNQ7JBU> <@U6TBZ66FN> can I get this ungated?
It should be ungated, but we may not be able to verify that combined css has the same rendering as un-combined. Let me check.
Which page? Can you let me know the URL?
<http://www.wolfpacsolutions.com/>
Thanks.
it happens on all pages where the menu shows up
i believe it is reading the normal browser css first and then loads teh css
Hmm. Try programaticly clicking the submit button instead.
I suspect it is a JS issue instead of CSS issue. Do you use JS to render stuff on the page?
not sure if this would help, but you could try to trigger the submit button rather than submitting the form directly like so `$( ".hs-form .hs-button" ).trigger( "click" );`
BTW, our verifier found about 19% diff when combined css, so it did not serve the combined version.
^^^I find this way to work the best now a days with hs forms
I'll try that
Yeah, that does seem to work better
Super weird
Thanks!
probably due to the way HubSpot's form scripts handle form submissions... maybe it's looking for a click on the button rather than form submit :grimacing:
ahh react.

<https://imgur.com/a/UvGmm>

it goes at #simple-menu
Can we remove the sidr.js and try?
removed

i think i see
its the mobile menu that is appearing like that

so what is going on is the dev isn’t hiding the mobile menu with css
but with js
so it shows first
and then once the js kciks in it hides the menu
I apologizing was wasting your time as a resource. This isn’t the way we build these menus so I didnt’ even think to look into this
No problem. Glad to be able to help

i think that is the issue
yeah
